dislike.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to think someone or something is unpleasant and not like them
dislike.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Why do you dislike her so much?
I dislike being the centre of attention.
dislike.translation[0].definitions[0].no: In everyday English, people usually say don’t like rather than dislike:
dislike.translation[0].note_box[0].items: Dislike is used with an -ing form, not an infinitive You dislike doing something
I dislike to eat dinner alone
Dislike is not used in the progressive You say
Tell us what you dislike about it
Tell us what you are disliking about it
dislike.translation[0].note_box[1].secti: dislike
to not like someone or something. Dislike is stronger than not like, and is used especially in written English
She disliked him as soon as she met him.
Chemistry was the only subject he disliked at school.
not like
Why did you invite Claire? You know I don’t like her.
I don’t really like getting up in the morning when it’s dark.
not be very keen on something
used to say that you do not like something, but in a polite or gentle way
I’m not very keen on Chinese food.
She’s never been very fond of his books.
not think much of somebody/something
to not like someone or something because you do not have a good opinion of them
We’ve tried that restaurant twice and we don’t think much of it.
I worked with him for years and I didn’t think much of him.
not be somebody’s kind of thing
to not be the kind of thing you enjoy – used about activities, films, books etc
Detective stories aren’t really my kind of thing.
go off somebody/something
to stop liking someone or something that you used to like
Dan and I went out together for six months and then I just went off him.
put somebody off somebody/something
to make you stop liking someone or something
I was terrible at sport at school and it totally put me off doing any kind of exercise.
dislike.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a feeling of not liking someone or something
dislike.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: They took an instant dislike to each other  (=they disliked each other immediately).
His colleagues regarded him with intense dislike.
She shared her mother’s dislike of housework.
Truman had a strong dislike for communism.
